pageDescription: An interactive educational tool to calculate and explore the bijective base-6 number system, which has no zero. Features a live converter and reference tables.
liveConverterDesc: Enter a decimal number to see its real-time representation across different systems.
calculatorDesc: Enter two bijective base-6 numbers to see the results for all operations.
primerDesc1: Most number systems we use are positional. This means the value of a digit depends on its position within a number. The "base" of a system tells us how many unique digits are used. The value of each position is an exponent of the base, starting from 0 on the right.
primerDesc2: In these standard systems, the digit zero is essential. It is not just a number, but a fundamental placeholder. It signifies an empty position, like the tens place in 101. The bijective system you are exploring is fascinating because it works without this placeholder.
explanationDesc1: This system is a bijective base-6 numeration. It is positional, but with two key differences: it has no zero, and its digits run from 1 to 6. Because there is no zero to act as a placeholder, the system "rolls over" differently. After 6, the next number is 11.
algoDesc: The trick to converting from decimal to bijective base-6 is to temporarily shift the number system. Computers naturally work with remainders from 0 to 5, but our digits are 1 to 6. We bridge this gap by subtracting 1 before each calculation.
applicationsDesc: Bijective numeration is more than a curiosity; it solves real-world problems in computer science.
advancedDesc: The properties of bijective numeration extend into more complex areas of computer science and mathematics, such as cryptography and algorithmic enumeration.
